Postprocessing problematic regions

Kaixuan Luo

2024-02-13

Source: vignettes/postprocessing_regions.Rmd
postprocessing_regions.Rmd

Overview

This document is a tutorial for fine-mapping problematic regions with LD mismatches. We will use the multigroup version of the package, but the procedure below works for using a single prediction model, or multiple prediction models.

Getting started

Install the multigroup_kevin branch of cTWAS package

remotes::install_github("xinhe-lab/ctwas", ref = "multigroup_kevin")

Load the package and set the working directory where you want to perform the analysis.

library(ctwas)
# set the working directory interactively
setwd("/project2/xinhe/shared_data/ctwas_tutorial")

# set the working directory when compiling this document with Knitr
knitr::opts_knit$set(root.dir = "/project2/xinhe/shared_data/ctwas_tutorial")

Follow the section on data preparation about harmonizing GWAS z-scores and LD reference and LD mismatch diagnosis.

First, we load the LD mismatch diagnosis result from running the preprocess_z_ld step, and gets a list of problematic SNPs with rsIDs.

outputdir <- "multigroup/processed_data/"
outname <- "example"

ld_mismatch_res <- readRDS(file.path(outputdir, paste0(outname, ".ld_mismatch_res.RDS")))
problematic_snps <- ld_mismatch_res$problematic_snps

You can also use those problematic SNPs (rsIDs) obtained by other tools, e.g. DENTIST.

Then, let’s load the cTWAS full result, and harmonized z_snp and z_gene data.

ctwas_res <- read.table(file.path(outputdir, paste0(outname, ".susieIrss.txt")), header=T)

# load processed z_snp file
load(file = file.path(outputdir, paste0(outname, ".harmonized.z_snp.Rd")))

# load processed z_snp file
load(file = file.path(outputdir, paste0(outname, "_z_gene.Rd")))

# harmonized prediction models
weight_dir <- "multigroup/processed_data/weights_nolnc/"
weight <- c(file.path(weight_dir, "mashr_Liver_nolnc_harmonized.db"), 
            file.path(weight_dir, "mashr_Adipose_Subcutaneous_nolnc_harmonized.db"))

We will rerun the fine-mapping step with L = 1 for the regions containing high PIP (>0.5) problematic SNPs or genes problematic SNPs in their weights.

The following function runs fine-mapping for the regions in parallel (with 6 cores) and saves results to [outname].L1.susieIrss.txt.

rerun_ctwas_finemap_regions_L1_rss(z_snp,
                                   z_gene,
                                   problematic_snps = problematic_snps,
                                   weight = weight,
                                   pip_thresh = 0.5,
                                   ctwas_outputdir = outputdir,
                                   ctwas_outname = outname,
                                   ncore = 6)
